title: Helen Westcott
text:
Helen Westcott (born Myrthas Helen Hickman, January 1, 1928 – March 17, 1998) was an American stage and screen actor and former <a href="child%20actor">child actor</a>. She is best known for her work in "<a href="The%20Gunfighter%20%28film%29">The Gunfighter</a>" (1950).
Early years.
Westcott was the daughter of singer Hazel Beth McArthur and <a href="Warner%20Bros.">Warner Bros.</a> <a href="Movie%20studio">studio</a> actor <a href="Gordon%20Westcott">Gordon Westcott</a>. Her father died when Helen was seven years old, in 1935.
When she was two, Westcott appeared in <a href="vaudeville">vaudeville</a> with her mother. At age seven, she began a nine-year run playing the daughter on stage in a production of "<a href="The%20Drunkard">The Drunkard</a>" in Los Angeles.
Westcott attended <a href="Los%20Angeles%20City%20College">Los Angeles City College</a>.
Film.
When Westcott was 4 years old, she appeared in a series of <a href="short%20film">short film</a>s. At 5, she appeared in the full-length "<a href="Thunder%20Over%20Texas">Thunder Over Texas</a>". She appeared opposite <a href="Gregory%20Peck">Gregory Peck</a> in the <a href="Western%20%28genre%29">western</a> classic "The Gunfighter" released in 1950. She was also known in part for her role in <a href="Charles%20Lamont">Charles Lamont</a>'s 1953 <a href="comedy%20horror">comedy horror</a> film "<a href="Abbott%20and%20Costello%20Meet%20Dr.%20Jekyll%20and%20Mr.%20Hyde">Abbott and Costello Meet Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde</a>".
Television.
Westcott moved from the big screen to television <a href="Character%20%28arts%29">roles</a> in the late 1950s. In 1958 she appeared on "<a href="Perry%20Mason%20%281957%20TV%20series%29">Perry Mason</a>" as murderer Marcia Greeley in "The Case of the Haunted Husband." She also made guest appearances on "<a href="Bonanza">Bonanza</a>", "<a href="The%20Twilight%20Zone">The Twilight Zone</a>" and "".
Later years.
Westcott also appeared on <a href="Theatre">the stage</a> later in her career, as well as in films including <a href="Anthony%20Mann">Anthony Mann</a>'s "<a href="God%27s%20Little%20Acre%20%28film%29">God's Little Acre</a>" in 1958.
Personal life.
Westcott wed actor <a href="Don%20Gordon%20%28actor%29">Don Gordon</a> on February 18, 1948. In 1950, they had a daughter, Jennifer. They were divorced in 1953.
Westcott was a registered <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> and a member of <a href="The%20Church%20of%20Jesus%20Christ%20of%20Latter-Day%20Saints">The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-Day Saints</a>.
Death.
Westcott died of cancer in <a href="Edmonds%2C%20Washington">Edmonds, Washington</a> on March 17, 1998. Her body was cremated.
Filmography.
Source: "The Encyclopedia of Fantastic Film: Ali Baba to Zombies"
